DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he hopes that additional funds for small business will be enough, while he added they will spend what it takes and that the cost of additional debt is low due to low rates. Furthermore, he added that they are looking forward to having most, if not all, of the economy open later in the summer. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said the House is to pass the latest COVID-19 relief bill on Thursday. (MSNBC)

Texas Governor said he will be making an important announcement next week regarding a reopen as Texans are not seeing the same severity as New York. (Newswires)

US COVID-19 cases +3.4% at 802,583 (prev. +4% at 776,093); death toll +6.7% at 44,575 (prev. +6.8% 41,758). (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 cases rose to 133,495 (prev. 129,044) and death toll rose to 18,100 (prev. 17,337); deaths increased by 759 (+4.4%) vs. yesterday's increase of 823 (+5.02%). (Newswires)

UK Foreign Minister Raab said we are beginning to come through the peak of the virus infections. (Newswires)

UK Chief Medical Advisor Whitty said the chances of having a vaccine in the next calendar year is incredibly small and until then, will need to rely on disruptive social distancing measures. (Newswires)

Swedish PM said it is not the correct time to ease COVID-19 restrictions and on the contrary, they are ready to do more if needed. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US strongly believes China did not report the coronavirus outbreak to the WHO in a timely fashion, while he added that the US strongly opposes China's bullying over Taiwan and the South China Sea. (Newswires)

BoJ are reportedly to cut their monetary policy meeting to one day next week to reduce the risk of infection among policy setters. (NHK)

 

UK/EU

EU Commission said to seek EUR 320bln to finance the regional recovery. (Newswires)

ECB said it has taken steps to mitigate the impact of potential debt rating downgrades on collateral availability in which marketable assets and issuers of these assets that met the minimum credit quality requirements for collateral eligibility on 7 April 2020 (BBB- for all assets, except asset-backed securities will continue to be eligible in case of rating downgrades, as long as their rating remains at or above credit quality step 5 (CQS5, equivalent to a rating of BB) on the Eurosystem harmonised rating scale. ECB said it is to grandfather until September 2021 eligibility of marketable assets used as collateral in Eurosystem credit operations falling below current minimum credit quality requirements and that appropriate haircuts will apply for assets that fall below the Eurosystem minimum credit quality requirements, while it may decide further measures if needed to continue ensuring the smooth transmission of its monetary policy in all jurisdictions of the euro area. (Newswires) 

 

FX

CBRT cut its Weekly Repo Rate by 100bps to 8.75% vs. Exp. 50bps cut and noted that risks to year-end inflation forecasts are to the downside. CBRT noted it should be emphasized that any new data or information may lead the Committee to revise its stance, while it stated that economic activity has started to weaken in mid-March due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic on external trade, tourism and domestic demand. (Newswires)

Canadian CPI Inflation (Mar) M/M -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Canadian CPI Inflation (Mar) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 2.2%)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 15.022M vs. Exp. 15.15M (Prev. 19.248M). (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the Trump administration is looking at different plans to support US oil prices and thinks oil will reach USD 30/bbl by August. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia are reportedly looking into the re-routing of tankers destined for the US in the event that the US imposes a ban on crude imports from Saudi Arabia, according to sources. (Newswires)

Saudi Aramco has started to scale back production from its maximum capacity (12mln BPD) in preparation for lowering its output to 8.5mln BPD in May, according to industry sources cited by Energy Intelligence. (Newswires)

US reportedly probes whether traders profited off tips on Russia at OPEC+. (Newswires)

USO may allocate 20% of its portfolio in June contracts (Prev. 40%), 50% in July (Prev. 55%), 20% in August (Prev. 5%) and 10% in September (Prev. 0%), while it had announced a one-for-eight reverse stock split for shares to take place on April 28th, at close of trading. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that he has instructed the United States Navy to shoot down and destroy any and all Iranian gunboats if they harass our ships at sea. In related news, US Secretary of State Pompeo said Iran needs to be held accountable for the IRGC and for looking to launch a satellite.(Newswires)

A senior Pentagon official said he has no reason not to assume North Korea leader Kim Jong Un is still leading the country. (Newswires)

 

US

US Senate Republican Leader McConnell said we will wait until at least next month to work on aid for states, while he added we will wait until at least May 4th and assess the effects of the stimulus before mulling a Phase 4 bill. Furthermore, McConnell stated we are not interested in revenue replacement for state governments or solving their pension problems and that state aid should be limited to virus issues. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Risk conditions bounced back on Wednesday, following Tuesday’s fall. The rise in crude prices was welcomed, although desks seem to suggest that Wednesday’s buying seems to be more a function of bargain hunting rather than any change to the overarching narrative. US Senators passing the so-called Stimulus Bill v3.5 was also said to have helped, with talk of a further stimulus bill to come (although the GOP does not seem to be fully behind it); attention will be on any infrastructure spending packages, after US President Trump recently floated a USD 2trln infrastructure ‘plan’. Apple Inc. (AAPL) will likely delay the release of its iPhone SE Plus to H2 21 from H1 21, according to 9to5Mac citing a report from TF Securities. Expedia Group (EXPE) is reportedly in advanced talks to sell a stake to Apollo (APO) and Silver Lake, according to WSJ sources, which note the deal is likely to total USD 1bln.  Activision Blizzard (ATVI) March videogame sales hit its highest level in 10 years amid lockdowns in place. Boeing Company (BA) announced it is making key changes to help create a greater cross-company integration. It has formed a new group, Enterprise Operation, which consolidates key operations. Sycamore Partners are looking to terminate its deal with L Brand (LB) on Victoria’s Secret. SPX +2.3% at 2799, NDX +3.1% at 8665, DJIA +2% at 23,476.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened amid the bounceback in risk appetite, lead by crude oil futures. After the 10-year yield fell below 0.55% on Tuesday, it today grinded back above 0.60%; at settlement, short end yields were relatively unchanged (2s around 0.21%), while long-end yields were up around 6bps (30s +6bps around 1.22%). The more constructive risk appetite coincided with raised dollar issuance, including several foreign issuers – such as the BoE (USD 2bln) and Mexico (USD 3bln) – which supported the swap spread compression seen on the session with a handful expected to swap. Meanwhile, other rates spreads compressed, too. The supportive risk tone saw credit default spread indices continue to move lower. At the same time, nearby Eurodollar contracts caught a bid as USD LIBOR posted further declines (the rest of the packs sold off in a steepener, similar to USTs), supporting a narrowing of FRA/LIBOR-OIS spreads; USD 3-month LIBOR-OIS sits around 90bps, down from its March peak of just beneath 140bps. T-notes (M0) settled 11 ticks lower at 139-01+.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 22nd: Oil bounces back supporting wider risk appetite
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: US puts pressure on Iran; crude futures bounce back, although storage issues remain; strong NFLX earnings.
  • COMING UP: Data: Australian PMIs, German, EZ, UK & US PMIs (Flash), US Initial Jobless Claims. Event: EU Conference on COVID-19. Earnings: Credit Suisse, Southwest Airlines, Eli Lilly, Union Pacific.

MARKET WRAP

Risk conditions bounced back on Wednesday, following Tuesday’s fall. The rise in crude prices was welcomed, although desks seem to suggest that Wednesday’s buying seems to be more a function of bargain hunting rather than any change to the overarching narrative. US Senators passing the so-called Stimulus Bill v3.5 was also said to have helped, with talk of a further stimulus bill to come (although the GOP does not seem to be fully behind it); attention will be on any infrastructure spending packages, after US President Trump recently floated a USD 2trln infrastructure ‘plan’. Equities are green, with all eleven sectors positive; strategy-wise, growth and momentum baskets have performed well, along with quality names. In credit, HYG outperformed investment grade; the Treasury curve bear-steepened with yields 1-6bps higher across the curve; gold ­– which some desks have said is back to trading as a function of real rates – higher; the DXY is slightly better than neutral, though its performance isn’t too much to sing home about. One interesting area is EMFX, which did start the US day mostly positive, but has succumbed to the buck strength over the course of the session.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

Figures provided as of Wednesday (via state official health departments) against Tuesday:

  • US: Cases +3.4% at 802,583 (prev. +4% at 776,093); death toll +6.7% at 44,575 (prev. +6.8% 41,758)
  • NEW YORK: Cases +2.4% at 257,216 (Prev.+1.7% at 251,690); death toll +474 (Prev. +3.4% (+481) to 14,828)
  • ITALY: Cases +1.83% at 187,327 (prev. +1.5% at 183,957); death toll +1.76% 25,083 (prev. +2.2% at 24,648)
  • UK: Cases rise to 133,495 (prev. 129,044), death toll rises to 18,100 (prev. 17,337); deaths rise by 759 (+4.4%) vs. yesterday's increase of 823 (+5.02%)
  • CANADA: Cases rise to 38,932 (prev. 37,382), death toll rises to 1,871 (prev. 1,728).

CRUDE

WTI and Brent June futures both bounced firmly off their lows from Tuesday - albeit only a partial retrace - and brought wider cross-asset risk appetite along with them, as the energy complex battles extreme volatility. The fundamental backdrop remains little changed, and how much information one can gauge out of today’s rally remains for debate. Citi’s analysts believe the bid is most likely “traders grabbing a perceived bargain, rather than any expectation that the surplus is disappearing or that the problem of finding a place to physically store the excess has been solved.” The energy complex also found some support after the EIA released inventories that were, relatively, more bullish than expectations: crude +15mln (exp. 15.2mln), Cushing +4.8mln, gasoline +1mln (exp. +3.6mln), distillates +7.9mln (exp. +2.8mln). While better than expected, the results are still chunky and reside in the upper quartiles of W/W changes, reflective of the supply drought and storage issues. Production fell slightly to 12.2mln BPD (-100k BPD), although that figure will likely need to come down markedly to provide some balance to the market. Meanwhile, the closely followed USO ETF reported it would carry out an 8-to-1 reverse stock split amid the price declines; additionally, it would be increasing its portfolio allocation further out the futures curve, to now include September expiry too.

OPEC: Russian Energy Minister Novak said global demand for crude has fallen by 20-30mln BPD and we are currently are at the bottom of the global oil demand decline. Novak says oil output cuts may total between 15-20mln BPD in May, which will help the situation. The Iranian Oil Minister said 100% compliance is seen from the start of May. Meanwhile, Nigeria will reportedly cut its output amid a lack of storage. IEA’s Birol has urged OPEC+ to cut output as soon as possible and recommended the group considers further cuts. Journalist Reza Zandi, citing a source, said that the decision to hold an extraordinary OPEC+ meeting had not been finalised yet; no date has been set yet, including the suggested date of May 10th; added that, logically, “another OPEC meeting might be organised at a date that could lead to a solution.”

WHITE HOUSE: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the administration is looking at different plans to support US oil prices – expressing that he believes oil will reach USD 30/bbl by August. The announcement follows from Trump’s tweet yesterday, where he indicated government support would be ensuing for the US Oil & Gas sector.

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS: As expected, the Senate unanimously passed the stimulus bill (version 3.5), a USD 500bln stimulus package, much of which will help prevent small businesses from closing and shedding jobs; the House will likely follow suit on Thursday, House Speaker Pelosi said so much today. From an economic perspective, keeping the jobless rate as low as possible will help to ensure that the eventual recovery is quicker; from a fiscal perspective, the implication is that the budget deficit will likely top 20% this year; and from the market’s perspective, there will be attention on how quickly these funds can get into the economy (UBS says that if the small business schemes are ‘running out of money’ it is a good sign those funds are filtering through). Democrats have framed v. 3.5 as an “interim measure” and have called on Congress to prepare another bill of similar size and ambition to the CARES Act. However, Republicans have endorsed a more cautious approach due to the amount of debt that the US is accumulating, which some Republicans have said is a major concern – as virus attention recedes, Republicans are likely to take a more hawkish tone on deficit spending. Looking ahead, the next point of focus is on infrastructure stimulus, which has already been talked up by US President Trump. Trump is open to a package including fiscal relief for states and local governments, and given that the Democrats wanted this relief in the current Bill, it seems it will be a bargaining chip for Trump in negotiations around infrastructure spending. Previously, Trump has touted a USD 2trln figure for infrastructure.

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB: The ECB held a call today to discuss whether or not junk debt should be able to be used as collateral. The call occurred amid concerns some of the worst-hit victims from COVID-19 could see a debt rating downgrade to junk, therefore their debt would not be able to be purchased by the ECB to support them. The decision allows for some junk debt to be accepted, where those who met the minim credit quality requirements on April 7th, will still be eligible in the event of a rating downgrade, as long as it remains or at above credit quality step 5, or BB. The move comes ahead of Friday’s sovereign rating on Italy by S&P, who currently have Italy two notches above IG with a negative outlook. Moody’s already rates Italy a notch above junk.  The ECB already accepts Greek debt as part of its easing programme, which is already rated junk. Currently, the rules state that Italy would have to be downgraded at each S&P, Moody’s, Fitch and DBRS for its debt to be excluded.

CBRT: The Turkish Central Bank opted to cut its Weekly Repo Rate by 100bps to 8.75% – at the top of analysts’ forecasts – taking real rates deeper into negative territory. Notably, the central bank assessed that risks to its year-end inflation forecasts are to the downside, adding that economic activity had started to weaken in mid-March due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic. On the Lira, the CBRT reiterated the impact of a soft currency’s effect on inflation is being offset by weaker oil prices, net/net a favourable impact. The Bank reaffirmed its “cautious monetary stance” and said it will be determined considering the indicators of the underlying inflation trend, but emphasised that any new data or information may lead the Committee to revise its stance. Desks note of three reasons which could’ve led to a deeper cut: 1) Looser global policies, 2) additional support to mitigate tail risks to growth, and 3) negative output gap affecting inflation. Analysts at ING said that the CBRT “does not signal that this is the final move of the cutting cycle”, but others argue that a sizeable rate hike may be on the agenda in the near future amid the CBRT’s dwindling reserves situation.

GEOPOLITICS

IRAN: US President Trump announced he has directed the US Navy to “shoot down and destroy any and all Iranian gunboats if they harass our ships at sea,” adding to the tensions between the two nations. US Secretary of State also noted that Iran needs to be held accountable for its militarily organization (IRGC) and for looking to launch a satellite. Elsewhere, in North Korea, a senior pentagon official noted he had no reason to believe Kim Jong Un was not still at the helm.

EUROPE

STIMULUS: The EU27 are poised to sign off on the plans concocted by EZ finance ministers on Thursday, and brainstorm on a long-term recovery plan. Leaders have signalled a general will for a larger coordinated fiscal response, albeit views seem to differ. Officials noted that the North fears that their financial positions will be contaminated by debt mutualisation in the future due to decisions taken by the South. The European Council is expected to discuss the size of a European Recovery Fund alongside other financing tools. The virtual meeting will be chaired by EU Council President Michel, although the lack of detailed proposals could see another impasse or delay in talks. Click here for the full Newsquawk primer.

UK: Chief Medical Advisor Whitty said the chances of having a vaccine in the next calendar year are incredibly small, and until then, will need to rely on disruptive social distancing measures.

EUROGROUP PRIMER: The EU27 are poised to sign off on the plans concocted by EZ finance ministers, and brainstorm on a long-term recovery plan. Leaders have signalled a general will for a larger coordinated fiscal response, albeit views seem to differ. Officials noted that the North fears that their financial positions will be contaminated by debt mutualisation in the future due to decisions taken by the South. The European Council is expected to discuss the size of a European Recovery Fund alongside other financing tools. The virtual meeting will be chaired by EU Council President Michel, although the lack of detailed proposals could see another impasse or delay in talks. Click here for full preview.

FIXED INCOME

T-NOTES (M0) SETTLED 11 TICKS LOWER AT 139-01+.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened amid the bounceback in risk appetite, lead by crude oil futures. After the 10-year yield fell below 0.55% on Tuesday, it today grinded back above 0.60%; at settlement, short end yields were relatively unchanged (2s around 0.21%), while long-end yields were up around 6bps (30s +6bps around 1.22%). The more constructive risk appetite coincided with raised dollar issuance, including several foreign issuers – such as the BoE (USD 2bln) and Mexico (USD 3bln) – which supported the swap spread compression seen on the session with a handful expected to swap. Meanwhile, other rates spreads compressed, too. The supportive risk tone saw credit default spread indices continue to move lower. At the same time, nearby Eurodollar contracts caught a bid as USD LIBOR posted further declines (the rest of the packs sold off in a steepener, similar to USTs), supporting a narrowing of FRA/LIBOR-OIS spreads; USD 3-month LIBOR-OIS sits around 90bps, down from its March peak of just beneath 140bps.

BANK ISSUANCE: BofA launched a USD 3bln 11-year NC10, similar to JPM last week, although they are the only two large US banks to issue debt post-earnings reports, a period that usually sees more activity. Note that banks have been making large credit provisions, as documented in Q1 reports, where the lack of debt raising being carried out is likely indicative of the group being well capitalised (for now), with the credit provisions being supportive enough to allow them to be patient until credit spreads narrow further to their pre-March blowup levels.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +2.3% at 2799, NDX +3.1% at 8665, DJIA +2% at 23,476.

SECTORS: IT +3.9%, Energy +3.6%, Communications +3.3%, Utilities +2.95%, Materials +2.1%, Consumer Discretionary +2%, Real Estate +1.9%, Health Care +1.6%, Industrials +1.15%, Financials +1.1%, Consumer Staples +1.1%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple Inc. (AAPL) will likely delay the release of its iPhone SE Plus to H2 21 from H1 21, according to 9to5Mac citing a report from TF Securities. Expedia Group (EXPE) is reportedly in advanced talks to sell a stake to Apollo (APO) and Silver Lake, according to WSJ sources, which note the deal is likely to total USD 1bln.  Activision Blizzard (ATVI) March videogame sales hit its highest level in 10 years amid lockdowns in place. Boeing Company (BA) announced it is making key changes to help create a greater cross-company integration. It has formed a new group, Enterprise Operation, which consolidates key operations. Sycamore Partners are looking to terminate its deal with L Brand (LB) on Victoria’s Secret.

EARNINGS: Netflix (NFLX) earnings were mixed, with EPS a miss and revenue a slight beat. Its global net additions however were solid rising to 15.77mln from 9.6mln, while it expects Q2 additions to be at 7.5mln, firmer than the expected 4.15mln. Q2 EPS and Revenue guidance came in beneath analyst expectations. Its regional breakdown was also solid, beating expectations in each region. Texas Instruments (TXN) beat on EPS and revenue, while guidance saw a wide margin. Delta Airlines (DAL) reported beat on loss per share, while revenue fell short; DAL also expects to finish June burning USD 50mln a day, down from USD 100mln a day currently. AT&T (T) EPS and revenue missed, although it maintained its dividend commitment. Postpaid phone net additions at 163k. Chipotle (CMG) beat on top and bottom line, March comp. sales -16%. Biogen (BIIB) beat on top and bottom line and sees the completion of US filing in Q3 on its Alzheimer’s drug Aducanumab. Snap (SNAP) missed on EPS, beat on revenue, while DAU’s rose 20% to 229mln.

DATA

CANADA CPI (MAR): Inflation slowed Y/Y to 0.9% from 2.2%, deeper than the expected 1.2%, while M/M saw CPI decline 0.6%, deeper than the expected fall of 0.4%. An average of the three BoC core measures ticked lower to 1.83% in March from 1.97%, moving further away from the BoC’s 2% target. Core CPI, however, maintained a 0.1% pace M/M, while Y/Y slowed to 1.6% from 1.8%. Reductions in prices in COVID-19 hit sectos included airlines, rental vehicles, and accommodation. Energy prices obviously weighed also. RBC notes that inflation is likely to slow significantly over the coming months, which could be a positive for consumers, but it depends upon the availability of these goods given social distancing measures in place. Although, the desk notes purchasing power in households will likely rise once these measures are eased.

EZ CONSUMER CONFIDENCE (APR.): Consumer Confidence fell to -22.7, a fresh record decline deeper than the expected fall of -19.6. The data excludes Italy, the worst hit country in the Eurozone, therefore the actual level of consumer confidence might actually be even worse than the data implies. Capital Economics highlights that consumption fell more sharply than implied by the data and also highlight that the data simply assumes that Italy fell in line with other EU nations. On consumption, CapEco suspects spending has fallen by 20-30% since the middle of March, noting spending in travel, restaurants, and hospitality has almost completely stopped, while the Bank of France announced bank card payments halved in late March. The consultancy now forecasts a 3.5% GDP contraction in Q1, and a 20% contraction in Q2 in the eurozone.

INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS PRIMER: This week’s initial jobless claims will coincide with the survey period for the BLS’ Employment Situation Report. Claims printed 5.245mln in the week ending April 11th; analysts had expected 5.105mln, from a revised 6.61mln. Oxford Economics said the data now appears to have reached a “vertiginous plateau.” Oxford Economics says that while it now appears that we have passed the peak in layoffs, “jobless claims are poised to remain extraordinarily high in coming weeks as the economy plunges deeper into a recession”. Since the latest report, the PPP funds had been depleted and congress have only just come to an agreement on the funding, with the house set to vote on the bill tomorrow (likely to pass). However, given this week there was no funding for the programme, desks have noted there could perhaps be some upside risk to the figure. Oxford Economics now anticipates the official nonfarm payrolls data for April will show a loss of 24 million jobs and the unemployment rate spiking to 14%, while the participation rate will fall beneath 60%. “While some jobs will be recouped as activity rebounds, we don’t expect the economy to reach the February 2020 level of employment until early 2022.”

FOREX

USD / EUR: The dollar firmed today continuing gains despite risk sentiment improving (desks have noted the inverse relationship of late). The gains likely stem from a weaker euro ahead of the ECB’s call on whether junk-rated debt will be able to be used as collateral, Thursday’s crunch European Summit, and Friday’s rating review of Italy. Focussing on Thursday’s meeting, Italian PM Conte has warmed to ESM credit lines while a coronabond plan is still premature; if Italy fails to win concessions, it could be particularly negative for the government, with Citi’s analysts suggesting that government stability might be at risl.

JPY: USDJPY traded within a tight 40pip range today and currently is flat against the greenback. In the months ahead, UBS expect USDJPY to head towards 100-102 levels given improved dollar liquidity across the globe. However, the desk highlights that although USD liquidity appears to have improved, FRA-OIS spread indicates we are still not yet back at “normal” levels. The return to normality depends on when lockdown restrictions are eased to see the return of corporate cash flows. A break of 100 to the downside is being blocked by subdued global growth, and thus UBS believe this could keep USDJPY between a 100-105 level in H2 20 and early 2021.

COMMODITY FX: The Loonie and Ruble seemed to benefit the most from today’s bounce of lows in the crude complex although NOK and MXN failed to reap the same rewards. ING is sceptical on CAD, given 10% of its GDP relies on the energy sector and worries it may be hit with a lag while it notes its stimulus plan will hardly avoid a sharp downturn. The desk holds USDCAD target at 1.45 in the upcoming weeks. The MXN continues to underperform after the Banxico’s emergency 50bp rate cut on Tuesday, which has likely offset any potential benefit from the oil move today. The Norwegian Krone also failed to benefit from the reversal in oil prices; TD securities highlights that EURNOK momentum stalled despite a break of 11.50/55 resistance, and states that FX purchases from Norges bank remain supportive, but spec positioning remains light and therefore hold a bias to purchase dips in EURNOK, although TD are cautious of a bounce in risk.

Cyclicals: (AUD/NZD/GBP): With an improvement in risk appetite AUD has appreciated against the buck (which is slightly firmer, still). The cross reclaimed 0.63 to the upside to highs of 0.6350 before consolidating. Retail sales were solid overnight reflecting the increase in stockpiling amid COVID-19. Although retail sales were decent, HSBC notes price action in Aussie today has been dictated by the combination of rising equities and short positioning.

GBP: Some note that the pound has traded as an oil proxy in recent sessions, although not today and cable is back above 1.2350; recently desks have had a 1.2350-12650 playbook with a bias of selling rallies. SocGen suggests that Thursday's PMI data could find buyers of EURGBP on any relative disappointment in UK PMIs vs EZ counterparts, and there is a fair chance of this occurring since the UK went on lockdown after Germany, France and Italy.

NZD: A different story for the Kiwi than Aussie and Sterling, NZD trades lower against the buck despite the risk-friendly sentiment on Wednesday. Perhaps a follow on from prior day losses spurred by further dovish commentary from the RBNZ which perhaps hints further easing is coming.

EMFX: Overall EMFX was weaker against the buck, apart from the RUB which appreciated with the price of oil. TRY relatively unchanged against the buck despite a deeper than expected rate cut from the CBRT which took its repo rate to 8.75% from 9.75%, which was at the top of the expected range, median was looking for a 50bp cut. ZAR traded marginally weaker amid CPI data which cooled to 0.3% from 1.0% M/M, while the Y/Y print slowed to 4.1% from 4.6%.

subject: TREASURY WRAP: T-Note futures (M0) settled 11 ticks lower at 139-01+
analysis_details:
• The Treasury curve bear-steepened amid the bounce back in risk appetite, lead by crude oil futures. After the 10-year yield fell below 0.55% on Tuesday, it today grinded back above 0.60%; at settlement, short end yields were relatively unchanged (2s around 0.21%), while long-end yields were up around 6bps (30s +6bps around 1.22%). The more constructive risk appetite coincided with raised dollar issuance, including several foreign issuers – such as the BoE (USD 2bln) and Mexico (USD 3bln) – which supported the swap spread compression seen on the session with a handful expected to swap. Meanwhile, other rates spreads compressed, too. The supportive risk tone saw credit default spread indices continue to move lower. At the same time, nearby Eurodollar contracts caught a bid as USD LIBOR posted further declines (the rest of the packs sold off in a steepener, similar to USTs), supporting a narrowing of FRA/LIBOR-OIS spreads; USD 3-month LIBOR-OIS sits around 90bps, down from its March peak of just beneath 140bps.
  • BANK ISSUANCE: BofA launched a USD 3bln 11-year NC10, similar to JPM last week, although they are the only two large US banks to issue debt post-earnings reports, a period that usually sees more activity. Note that banks have been making large credit provisions, as documented in Q1 reports, where the lack of debt raising being carried out is likely indicative of the group being well capitalised (for now), with the credit provisions being supportive enough to allow them to be patient until credit spreads narrow further to their pre-March blowup levels.

subject: ECB says it has taken steps to mitigate the impact of potential debt rating downgrades on collateral availability
content:
Marketable assets and issuers of these assets that met the minimum credit quality requirements for collateral eligibility on 7 April 2020 (BBB- for all assets, except asset-backed securities (ABSs)) will continue to be eligible in case of rating downgrades, as long as their rating remains at or above credit quality step 5 (CQS5, equivalent to a rating of BB) on the Eurosystem harmonised rating scale.

  • ECB to grandfather until September 2021 eligibility of marketable assets used as collateral in Eurosystem credit operations falling below current minimum credit quality requirements
  • Appropriate haircuts will apply for assets that fall below the Eurosystem minimum credit quality requirements
  • Decision reinforces broader package of collateral easing measures adopted by the Governing Council on 7 April 2020, which will also remain in place until September 2021
  • ECB may decide further measures, if needed, to continue ensuring the smooth transmission of its monetary policy in all jurisdictions of the euro area

Click here for link
analysis_details:
• The move comes ahead of Friday’s sovereign rating on Italy by S&P, who currently have Italy two notches above IG with a negative outlook. The call comes amid the worry of coronavirus induced downgrades from rating agencies, therefore the ECB may be acting pre-emptively to ensure debt can still be used as collateral, even if it was downgraded to Junk.
  • Moody’s already rates Italy a notch above junk.  
  • The ECB already accepts Greek debt as part of its easing programme, which is already rated junk.
  • Currently, the rules are that Italy would have to be downgraded at each S&P, Moody’s, Fitch and DBRS for its debt to be excluded.

CRUDE SETTLEMENT: WTI (M0) settles USD 2.21 higher at USD 13.78/bbl; WTI (N0) settles USD 2.00 higher at USD 20.69/bbl; Brent (M0) settles USD 1.04 higher at USD 20.37/bbl
analysis_details:
• WTI and Brent Junefutures both bounced firmly off their lows from Tuesday - albeit only a partial retrace - and brought wider cross-asset risk appetite along with them. The fundamental backdrop remains little changed, and how much information one can gauge out of today’s rally is debatable. Citi’s analysts believe the bid is most likely “traders grabbing a perceived bargain, rather than any expectation that the surplus is disappearing or that the problem of finding a place to physically store the excess has been solved.” The energy complex also found some support after the EIA released inventories that were, relatively, more bullish than expectations: crude +15mln (exp. 15.2mln), Cushing +4.8mln, gasoline +1mln (exp. +3.6mln), distillates +7.9mln (exp. +2.8mln). While better than expected, the results are still chunky and reside in the upper quartiles of W/W changes, reflective of the supply drought and storage issues. Production fell slightly to 12.2mln BPD (-100k BPD), although that figure will likely need to come down markedly to provide some balance to the market. Meanwhile, the closely followed USO ETF reported it would carry out an 8-to-1 reverse stock split amid the price declines; additionally, it would be increasing its portfolio allocation further out the futures curve, to now include September expiry too.
  • OPEC: Russian Energy Minister Novak said global demand for crude has fallen by 20-30mln BPD and we are currently are at the bottom of the global oil demand decline. Novak says oil output cuts may total between 15-20mln BPD in May, which will help the situation. The Iranian Oil Minister said 100% compliance is seen from the start of May. Meanwhile, Nigeria will reportedly cut its output amid a lack of storage. IEA’s Birol has urged OPEC+ to cut output as soon as possible and recommended the group consider further cuts. Journalist Reza Zandi, citing a source, said that the decision to hold an extraordinary OPEC+ meeting had not been finalised yet; no date has been set yet, including the suggested date of May 10th; added that, logically, “another OPEC meeting might be organised at a date that could lead to a solution.”
  • WHITE HOUSE: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the administration is looking at different plans to support US oil prices – expressing that he believes oil will reach USD 30/bbl by August. The announcement follows from Trump’s tweet yesterday, where he indicated government support would be ensuing for the US Oil & Gas sector.

Daily FX Wrap: crude reawakening and CBRT rear-guard action
content:
AUD/CAD/GBP/NZD/RUB/ZAR

A considerably better day for most currencies inextricably linked to the fortunes of oil and other commodities, with the Aussie also belatedly boosted by a record rise in retail sales even though stocking up for COVID-19 inflated the unprecedented level of consumer demand. Aud/Usd rebounded to around 0.6350 on a mixture of short covering and stops, but the pair has pared back since towards the 0.6300 handle in advance of April PMIs. Meanwhile, the Loonie hardly flinched in the face of weaker than forecast Canadian CPI data as crude prices rebounded further from extreme lows on a combination of consolidation and supportive verbal intervention from Russia and the US, with Usd/Cad more than 100 pips down from highs over 1.4230 at one stage. Elsewhere, the Pound staged an impressive comeback from Tuesday’s lows, but topped out ahead of 1.2400 vs its US counterpart amidst few if any fresh UK specific drivers as was the case when Sterling suffered heavy losses in preceding sessions. Back down under, the Kiwi latched on to its Antipodean peer’s coattails and popped above 0.6000 before losing momentum and altitude with Nzd/Usd now sub-0.5950 and Aud/Nzd testing 1.0600. In the EM space, respite for the Rouble as Brent reclaims Usd 20/brl-plus status vs a fraction below Usd 16 at worst, as Usd/Rub hovers close to the bottom end of 77.6750-75.8200 parameters, while the Rand has bounced from 19.0600 or so on a broader recovery in risk sentiment that has become increasingly correlated with the mood in oil markets rather than remaining weak on the back of softer than expected SA inflation metrics. However, headline CPI is now beneath the midpoint of the SARB’s 3-6% target range and could presage more easing irrespective of the benchmark rate already residing at an all time low.

EUR/CHF/JPY

All giving up ground to the Greenback in late trade as the DXY regains composure amidst bear re-steepening along the US Treasury curve and retrieves 100.000+ territory compared to 99.881 at the other end of the spectrum. Eur/Usd is losing sight of 1.0850 following a miss in Eurozone consumer confidence, Usd/Chf is looking firmer within a 0.9718-0.9669 band and Usd/Jpy is edging closer to 108.00 than 107.50.

NOK/MXN/BRL/TRY

The Norwegian Crown and Mexican Peso have lost impetus from the aforementioned crude revival, while the Brazilian Real is succumbing to catch-up selling following yesterday’s national holiday, but the Turkish Lira is just keeping its head above 7.0000 despite the CBRT slashing rates by 100 bp vs consensus for -1/2 point (though in range of estimates) and delivering a dovish assessment of the inflation outlook (risks skewed to the downside of year end projections) with the aid of local bank Usd/Try selling. Note also, ahead of the policy meeting FX swap limits were raised to 30% from 20% and this capped gains towards the touted line in the sand psychological level.

subject: PRIMER: Eurogroup Summit on Thursday; Lack of detailed proposals could see another impasse or delay in negotiations
content:
*OVERVIEW: The EU27 are poised to sign off on the plans concocted by EZ finance ministers, and brainstorm on a long-term recovery plan. Leaders have signalled a general will for a larger coordinated fiscal response, albeit views seem to differ. Officials noted that the North fears that their financial positions will be contaminated by debt mutualisation in the future due to decisions taken by the South. The European Council is expected to discuss the size of a European Recovery Fund alongside other financing tools. The virtual meeting will be chaired by EU Council President Michel, although the lack of detailed proposals could see another impasse or delay in talks.

*EU RECOVERY FUND: The Council President said the Fund should be established as soon as possible to kick-start economy once lockdown measures are eased, but officials note of a large divide between member states on the size and whether it should consist of only grants or solely loans. Consensus on a Recovery Fund this week has been heavily downplayed, with officials pointing to more clarity in June or July. In terms of the nuances, Spain is to propose a EUR 1.5tln recovery fund backed by perpetual bonds to finance the recovery of the worst-hit countries in grants and not loans, to avoid rising debt. France has backed the principals in Spain’s proposal but noted a physical meeting will be needed for a formal decision, potentially before Summer – President Macron previously said there is no choice but to set up a joint EUR 400bln recovery fund. Sources said the European Commission is reportedly seeking EUR 320bln to finance the regional recovery.

*EUROGROUP FALLOUT: At the Eurogroup meeting, Finance Ministers agreed on a EUR 540bln rescue package which consists of:

  • ESM CREDIT LINE (up to 2% of Euro Area GDP): This will be immediately available for member states with “light” conditionality. The size could be up to USD 240bln should all countries tap the maximum available. This also opens the door to Outright Monetary Transactions (OMT) by the ECB, which allows the Central Bank to purchase unlimited debt from the worst-hit regions, albeit some analysts have suggested that the OMT programme has already been made redundant by the ECB's new PEPP.
  • FIRMING EIB ACTIVITIES (up to 1.6% of Euro Area GDP): The European Investment Bank could support EUR 200bln of company financings, with emphasis on SMEs.
  • SHORT-TIME WORK SCHEME (0.8% of Euro Area GDP): The EUR 100bln scheme was drafted to aid protect jobs and workers hit by the pandemic in the form of loans on “favourable” terms.

*CORONABOND: The common debt issuances pursued namely by Spain and Italy was not included in the Eurogroup’s draft document after experiencing pushback by several larger members, vehemently from Austria, Germany and Netherlands. However, Italy seems to be erring towards a compromise on the issue. Italian PM Conte, at a Senate hearing on Tuesday, signalled open-mindedness towards the ESM credit line and an alternative fund as a substitute to Eurobonds. Desks note that this should reduce tail risks for a roadblock.

*ITALY’S DILEMMA: PM Conte set a high bar for success in negotiations for a post-virus response as domestic pressure builds at the epicentre of the European outbreak. Desks note that the PM will need a win to confine the rising Eurosceptics whilst fending off opposition parties waiting to muster support from any failures. Despite Conte’s more recent sanguine tone regarding a Coronabond compromise, participants believe the PM could be tempted to walk away from the table, having had battled for weeks on a Euro-wide debt instrument. Meanwhile, domestic pushback could arise from a compromise of just ESM lines – potentially paving a way for a change in government. It’s also worth noting that S&P will be reviewing Italy’s sovereign debt on Friday; the agency will be eyeing the outcome of negotiations. Credit Suisse believes that the survival of the Euro could be at risk if EU leaders fail to understand the difficultly in Italy’s economical and political landscapes.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN NOTE: Indices and sectors open in the green rebounding from prior day losses
content:
MACRO: Sentiment has improved somewhat with equities trading higher in Europe and gains following in the US. Oil prices – which have been dictating the action in recent sessions – have partially rebounded, with the crude complex off worst levels; upside was seen after US President Trump announced he directed the US Navy to “shoot down and destroy any and all Iranian gunboats if they harass our ships at sea”, adding to geopolitical tensions between the two sides. The US stimulus bill also passed last night, which may be contributing, although it was widely expected. Some desks believe it is just a technical bounce being seen this morning. Elsewhere, USD is slightly softer but DXY remains above 100, while yields are higher, albeit flat in the short end with the curve bear-steepening.

SECTORS: All sectors trade are in positive territory, with Energy outperforming as oil rises off its recent lows. Cyclicals, Tech and Materials, also performing well expressing a risk friendly environment while defensives, Staples and Health Care and at the bottom of the pack, albeit still in positive territory.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple Inc. (AAPL) will likely delay the release of its iPhone SE Plus to H2 21 from H1 21, according to 9to5Mac citing a report from TF Securities. Expedia Group (EXPE) is reportedly in advanced talks to sell a stake to Apollo (APO) and Silver Lake, according to WSJ sources, which note the deal is likely to total USD 1bln.  Activision Blizzard (ATVI) March videogame sales hit its highest level in 10 years amid lockdowns in place. Boeing Company (BA) announced it is making key changes to help create a greater cross-company integration. It has formed a new group, Enterprise Operation, which consolidates key operations.

EARNINGS: Netflix (NFLX) earnings were mixed, with EPS a miss and revenue a slight beat. Its global net additions however were solid rising to 15.77mln from 9.6mln, while it expects Q2 additions to be at 7.5mln, firmer than the expected 4.15mln. Q2 EPS and Revenue guidance came in beneath analyst expectations. Its regional breakdown was also solid, beating expectations in each region. Texas Instruments (TXN) beat on EPS and revenue, while guidance saw a wide margin. Delta Airlines (DAL) reported beat on loss per share, while revenue fell short; DAL also expects to finish June burning USD 50mln a day, down from USD 100mln a day currently. AT&T (T) EPS and revenue missed, although it maintained its dividend commitment. Postpaid phone net additions at 163k. Chipotle (CMG) beat on top and bottom line, March comp. sales -16%. Biogen (BIIB) beat on top and bottom line and sees the completion of US filing in Q3 on its Alzheimer’s drug Aducanumab. Snap (SNAP) missed on EPS, beat on revenue, while DAU’s rose 20% to 229mln.

US STIMULUS V. 3.5: As expected, the Senate unanimously passed the so-called stimulus bill version 3.5, a USD 500bln stimulus package, much of which will help prevent small businesses from closing and shedding jobs; the House will likely follow suit on Thursday. From an economic perspective, keeping the jobless rate as low as possible will help to ensure that the eventual recovery is quicker; from a fiscal perspective, the implication is that the budget deficit will likely top 20% this year; and from the market's perspective, there will be attention on how quickly these funds can get into the economy (UBS says that if the small business schemes are 'running out of money' it is a good sign those funds are filtering through. Looking ahead, the next point of focus is on infrastructure stimulus, which has already been talked up by US President Trump. Trump is open to a package including fiscal relief for states and local governments, and given that the Democrats wanted this relief in the current Bill, it seems it will be a bargaining chip for Trump in negotiations around infrastructure spending. Previously, Trump has touted a USD 2trln figure for infrastructure. 

SHAKE-OUT: Nomura's quants explain Tuesday's downside in equities as an expected shake-out of long positions. The bank says it appears that CTAs have halted adding to longs in NASDAQ 100 futures, and Nomura says the focus is now whether NDX can remain above the 'trigger line' of 8,180. Technically, it thinks CTAs may look to add longs towards month-end, providing that trigger line is not breached, but if such an upside attempt were to fail to squeeze some investors out of shorts or convince others to stake out fresh longs, Nomura expects CTA buying pressure may fizzle out in May. "This would imply a need to brace for selling in tune with the “sell in May” adage." Meanwhile, the funds that appear the least interested in buying have been fundamentally-focused. "In particular, the global heavyweights among macro hedge funds are still bearish on equities, and we suspect that global macro hedge funds will remain bearish until there is some reason to believe that DM economies are on their way to finding a floor." If economic indicators bottom, the bank's quants think global macro hedge funds might have to make an emergency rush to exit shorts; "however, our impression is that there is not much impetus among global macro hedge funds to rethink their current strategies just now."

subject: ANALYSIS: Senate passed Stimulus v. 3.5; attention now on implementation and next phase of support
analysis_details:
• As expected, the Senate unanimously passed the so-called stimulus bill version 3.5, a USD 500bln stimulus package, much of which will help prevent small businesses from closing and shedding jobs; the House will likely follow suit on Thursday.
  • From an economic perspective, keeping the jobless rate as low as possible will help to ensure that the eventual recovery is quicker; from a fiscal perspective, the implication is that the budget deficit will likely top 20% this year; and from the market's perspective, there will be attention on how quickly these funds can get into the economy (UBS says that if the small business schemes are 'running out of money' it is a good sign those funds are filtering through.
  • Democrats have framed v. 3.5 as an “interim measure” and have called on Congress to prepare another bill of similar size and ambition to the CARES Act. However, Republicans have endorsed a more cautious approach due to the amount of debt that the US is accumulating, which some Republicans have said is a major concern.
  • Looking ahead, the next point of focus is on infrastructure stimulus, which has already been talked up by US President Trump. Trump is open to a package including fiscal relief for states and local governments, and given that the Democrats wanted this relief in the current Bill, it seems it will be a bargaining chip for Trump in negotiations around infrastructure spending. Previously, Trump has touted a USD 2trln figure for infrastructure.

subject: PRIMER: The ECB will today hold a call to consider adding junk-debt to its accepted list of collateral
analysis_details:
• The call is set to take place in the evening, and there is no indication on how any outcome will be communicated.
  • The call has reportedly been prompted by the possibility that some bonds in Europe could be downgraded by CRAs to junk due to the fallout of COVID-19.
  • HSBC notes that Italian government debt is currently rated two notches above junk, but the sovereign has a negative outlook at Moody’s, and any downgrade on Friday would put it just a notch above junk. Meanwhile, Moody’s already rates Italy a notch above junk.
  • The ECB already accepts Greek debt as part of its easing programme, which is already rated junk.
  • “The central role of the ECB as the pan-European response to COVID-19 has long been evident,” HSBC says, “EU leaders meet tomorrow with little expectation of any progress towards fiscal burden sharing. But, ECB action means debt mutualisation is effectively happening.”

content:
• The March CPI data will be the first to show the effect from COVID-19, and the consensus expects a print of -0.4% M/M (prev. +0.4%), and the Y/Y rate is seen falling to 1.2% from 2.2%.
  • RBC highlights that the expected collapse will be mainly due to the fall in gas prices, which could shave around 0.9ppts from the Y/Y print, and add that "demand destruction will outweigh supply side factors in seeing inflation around 0.0% Y/Y in Q2 20 through Q1 21".
  • The BOC’s core measures are expected to trend lower from the central bank’s 2% target (where it has been lingering recently); RBC maintains a downside bias for the March data. For reference, the three BOC core measures averaged 1.97% in February.

subject: CBRT cuts its Weekly Repo Rate by 100bps to 8.75% (top end of expected range); risks to year-end inflation forecasts are to the downside
content:
• It should be emphasized that any new data or information may lead the Committee to revise its stance
  • Economic activity has started to weaken in mid-March due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic on external trade, tourism and domestic demand
  • Despite the recent depreciation in the Turkish lira due to global developments, continued sharp decline in international commodity prices, especially crude oil and metal prices, affects inflation outlook favorably.
  • Monetary stance will be determined by considering the indicators of the underlying inflation trend to ensure the continuation of the disinflation process.
  • The Central Bank will continue to use all available instruments in pursuit of the price stability and financial stability objectives.
  • Link
reaction_details: • TRY strengthened heading into the decision, with USD/TRY reaching sub-6.9700 levels. However, amid a deeper-than-forecast cut (deeper negative real rates) alongside risks to year-end inflation forecasts to the downside, the pair rose to a high of 6.9950

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 22nd April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer by around 1% and overall little moved from opening levels; stateside, futures show a similar pattern
  • Crude futures are currently subdued but have been choppy throughout the session with WTI alternating between positive & negative territory
  • US Senate approved the new USD 480bln coronavirus relief bill as expected by unanimous consent, which the House is set to vote on this Thursday
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he think this will be last tranche of money for small business although more can be added in the future
  • Iraq Energy Minister said OPEC+ could take additional steps to absorb the oil surplus; IEA’s Birol has suggested producers consider further cuts
  • Looking ahead, highlights include CBRT Rate Decision, Canadian CPI, EZ Consumer Confidence, DoEs, earnings from Delta Airlines, AT&T, Kimberly-Clark

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US Senate approved the new USD 480bln coronavirus relief bill as expected by unanimous consent, which the House is set to vote on this Thursday. This follows earlier reports of a bipartisan deal to expand virus aid which includes USD 250bln+ for the Payment Protection Program, USD 60bln more for small lenders, USD 60bln in disaster relief loans, USD 75bln for hospitals and USD 25bln for testing. (Newswires) US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said the next coronavirus relief debate should take place when full Senate is in session considering the nation's debt burden and House Speaker Pelosi commented the next coronavirus bill will happen very soon. (Newswires)

US President Trump said 20 states are moving along pretty quickly towards reopening and that the country wants to return to work. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he think this will be last tranche of money for small business although more can be added in the future, while he also stated that broadband and infrastructure is important for phase 4 relief and that it is premature to say how much phase 4 of relief will cost. (Newswires)

Spain's coronavirus cases stand at 208,389 (Prev. 204,178), according to the Health Ministry; deaths rise by 435 to 21,717 (Prev. 21,282). Spanish PM Sanchez says the goal is to de-escalate lockdown measures in the second half of May. (Newswires)

German Federal Institute for Vaccines says that a clinical test of a COVID-19 vaccine in Germany has gained approval; 4th such approved test in the world. (Newswires)

Japanese Economy Minister states that there has been no concrete talks with experts regarding lifting the State of Emergency. (Newswires)

Roche (ROG SW) CEO states he is afraid the most likely scenario is that there would not be a COVID-19 vaccine available before the end of next year, finds the 12-18 month timeline ambitious. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets initially extended on losses as the subdued tone rolled over once again from Wall St where sentiment was pressured by the continued oil market rout, but initially finished relatively mixed. Price action included the WTI June contract prices briefly slipping to single digits and with underperformance in tech amid President Trump’s plans for an immigration ban given the sector’s reliance on foreign talent. ASX 200 (U/C) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were weaker with Australia dragged lower by the mining related sectors and as corporate updates trickled in with Beach Energy also suffering from softer quarterly production, while the Japanese benchmark briefly fell below 19k as the recent detrimental currency flows reverberated across exporter names. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) conformed to the subdued global risk tone but with losses in the mainland limited by anticipation of further support after Chinese President Xi pledged stronger macro policy tools to soften the epidemic fallout and the State Council noted that China will boost targeted assistance to those in need, as well as small businesses. Finally, 10yr JGBs advanced as the took advantage of the weakness in stocks and amid the BoJ’s presence in the market today for JPY 710bln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 3yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0903 vs. Exp. 7.0840 (Prev. 7.0752)

Chinese President Xi said China will use stronger macro policy tools to soften the epidemic fallout while making sure the epidemic will not rebound. (Newswires)

China's Government is reportedly considering late-May for the National People's Congress, following the forced delay of this. (Newswires)

HKMA is to introduce a temporary USD liquidity facility to make available USD liquidity assistance for licensed banks. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump reiterated he will issue a temporary suspension of immigration and stated the measure will be in effect for 60 days then will be evaluated after, while he added it will apply to those seeking permanent residency and that the executive order on immigration will probably be signed today. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BoE Governor Bailey said Britain should be cautious about lifting lockdown too early and suggested lifting lockdown then slamming on brakes again would damage the economy even more. (Daily Mail)

UK CPI YY (Mar) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.7%); MM (Mar) 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.4%)

-        Core CPI YY (Mar) 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.7%); MM (Mar) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.6%)

ECB President Lagarde says primary market purchase of gov't debt would undermine sound budgetary policy requirements in EU treaty; the Governing Council has not discussed the issue of helicopter money. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn says the Governing Council will do everything necessary to ensure supportive financing conditions amid the pandemic; it is necessary to support the most severely hit countries; half of the IMF member have approached for emergency financing. (Newswires)

EU officials note of a large divide between member states on whether the virus Recover Fund should be only grants or only loans

-        Member states in the North and South must be reassured in the recovery discussion, adding that it will take time

-        North fears that their financial positions will be contaminated by debt mutualisation in the future due to decisions taken by the South

-        There is a misunderstanding that the South wants to use the coronavirus crisis to burden the North with old debt

-        Further clarity on the recovery fund could become greater in June/July but it would still not likely be the final decision

-        There is no agreement between member states on the needed size of the fund or how such money should be spent

Riksbank are to purchase municipal bonds for a nominal amount of SEK 15bln between 27th April and 30th June. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said we don't know about North Korea Leader Kim's health and that nobody has confirmed if he is ill, while other reports noted that North Korea succession is thought to mean that if Leader Kim dies, his sister would be the custodian of power. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc (TMO) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 2.94 (exp. 2.81), Revenue 6.23bln (exp. 6.18bln)

European equity futures see tailwinds from the turnaround in sentiment at the end of the APAC session (Euro Stoxx 50 +1.1%), with US equity futures also posting gains in excess of 1% in early trade. Sectors see broad-based gains, albeit energy lags as the complex remains under pressure from storage scarcity. In term of the breakdown, Tech names lead the gains following earnings from STMicroelectronics (+6.2%), whilst the sector also sees tailwinds from Texas Instruments (+3.0% pre-mkt), with the former, despite misses on its metrics, noted that Q1 was exited with stable net financial position, over USD 2.5bln in liquidity and available credit facilities above USD 1bln. Looking at other movers, Roche (+1.7%) is supported post earnings in which it topped estimates and pharma sales rose 7% YY. The Co. also stated that Clinical Phase III study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Actemra/Roactemra in severe COVID-19 pneumonia is ongoing in several countries, with results expected in early summer, adding there is capacity for a rapid increase of production. On the flip side, Credit Suisse (+0.4%) is hampered vs. the region after it stated it is to take an additional EUR 900mln loan loss provisions in Q1. Finally, other earnings-related movers include Akzo Nobel (+7.9%), Ericsson (+6.4%) and Kering (-5.42), the latter reported a decline in Gucci sales of 23.2% YY.

FX

AUD/NZD/CAD - Another swing in broad risk sentiment amidst less pronounced pressure on oil and other commodities has aided the latest Aussie, Kiwi and Loonie recovery, but with the former also benefiting from a short squeeze in wake of a record rise in retail sales per preliminary data for March. Aud/Usd took some time to digest the release and acknowledge the fact that stock-piling for COVID-19 boosted consumption, but subsequently breached 0.6300 on the way to circa 0.6350 with stops tripped above 0.6325 and macro fund offers over 0.6340 absorbed along the way. Meanwhile, Nzd/Usd retested 0.6000, albeit with a lag as Aud/Nzd rebounded from sub-1.0550 to around 1.0580, and Usd/Cad has retreated between 1.4237-1.4139 parameters on the aforementioned relative stability in crude prices ahead of Canadian CPI.

GBP/SEK/NOK  - Sterling has unwound some of its recent underperformance on technical rather than fundamental grounds given Cable remaining above the 30 DMA (1.2257) and revisiting 1.2300+ levels, while Eur/Gbp has reversed towards 0.8800 as the DXY meanders within a tight band on the 100.000 handle and single currency continues to straddle 1.0850. Similarly, the Scandis are seeing some reprieve from oil and pandemic risk aversion, with Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek both off highs near 11.5950 and 10.9700 respectively and the Swedish Krona weighing up more unconventional Riksbank easing in the form of municipal QE in the run up to next week’s official policy meeting.

JPY/EUR/CHF - All sticking to pretty narrow and well trodden recent confines vs the Dollar, as the Yen flits from 107.86 to 107.52, Euro hovers below 1.0900 and above 1.0800 amidst decent option expiry interest at the former (1.5 bn) and 1.0825 (1 bn), and Franc pivots 0.9700.

EM - Softer than expected SA CPI has not hindered the Rand amidst the overall upturn in risk appetite, but the Lira is treading more cautiously into the CBRT even though the Central Bank has already lifted FX swap limit transactions to 30% from 20% in what may be an effort to keep Usd/Try under 7.0000 in the event that rates are cut again, as widely expected, but perhaps more than the -50 bp consensus. On that note, the Mexican Peso seems to have taken Banxico’s emergency ½ point ease in stride or at least lubricated by the less fractious state of trade in crude markets.

Australian Retail Sales (Mar P) 8.2% (Prev. 0.5%); largest increase on record. ABS said the March sales data indicated unprecedented demand for food retailing industry. (Newswires)

FIXED

Core bonds have settled down somewhat after steeper retracement to 172.36, 136.63 and 139-05 lows for Bunds, Gilts and 10 year US T-notes respectively amidst an upturn in risk sentiment and semblance of stability in crude prices. However, Spanish Bonos are now encountering the same kind of issuance pressure that Italian BTPs suffered yesterday ahead of the 2030 syndicated pricing and final terms even though investor demand has exceeded previous record levels.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month futures remain choppy, but ultimately mixed this morning, with WTI swinging between gains and losses whilst Brent remained in the red for the entirety of the session thus far. Yesterday, OPEC Delegates discussed the oil market crisis within a conference call; although the call was reportedly not designed to make a new oil decision and they were said to consider a May 10th meeting for further production cuts. Furthermore, Saudi, UAE, and Kuwait did not take part in the call and a delegate noted that OPEC+ members will be unable to start production cuts earlier because April's oil production is already committed for export contracts. Meanwhile, the Iraq Energy Minister said OPEC+ could take additional steps to absorb the oil surplus but added that taking further measures by producer countries depends on global market development and compliance by other OPEC+ and other non-member producers with the oil cut deal. Russia again downplayed the gravitas of the oil market situation. Elsewhere, the fallout from the Texas Railroad Commission meeting saw two out of three Texas Oil and Gas regulators stated they are not ready to vote on oil output cuts today and they are to revisit the issue on May 5th. Sticking with North America, sources stated that producers in Alberta, Canada have reportedly already voluntarily cut 400k-700k BPD, according to Energy Intel. The contracts saw further downside as EU trade got underway, with WTI June resided under USD 11/bbl whilst Brent held onto losses of over 10% and eyed USD 17/bbl to the downside; however, since then we have recovered somewhat in what has been choppy trade for the complex but, ultimately, are in proximity to the lows – particularly for WTI, which ekes mild gains at the time of writing. Looking at the metals market, spot gold benefits from the Dollar pullback and reclaimed its USD 1700/oz handle. While copper trades subdued around USD 2.25/bbl, with miner Antofagasta stating that Q1 copper production rose almost 5% YY.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks +13.2mln vs. Exp. +15.2mln (Prev. +13.1mln). (Newswires)

CME will permit listing of negative oil options from today. CME also announced to raise crude oil NYMEX margins by 13.3% to USD 8500/contract from USD 7500/contract and raised NY Harbor Heating Oil margins by 16.3% to USD 5350/contract from USD 4600/contract for May, while it raised natgas Henry Hub futures margins by 6.1% to USD 1750/contract from USD 1650/contract and raised RBOB gasoline futures margins by 14.1% to USD 8,100/contract from USD 7,100/contract. (Newswires)

Iraq Energy Minister said OPEC+ could take additional steps to absorb the oil surplus but added that taking further measures by producer countries depends on global market development and compliance by other OPEC+ and other non-member producers with the oil cut deal. (Newswires)

Australia Energy Minister said they are to establish a strategic fuel reserve with initial allocation of AUD 94mln and want to take advantage of low fuel prices, while the government is working with industry to establish local storage and signed a deal with US to access fuel reserves. (Newswires)

The collapse of Singapore oil trader Hin Leong which filed for bankruptcy protection and is under investigation for hundreds of millions of undisclosed losses, risks a severe liquidity crunch for Singapore’s commodities sector. (FT)

Nigeria is to reduce oil output amid a lack of storage, according to Premium Times.

Energy Intelligence's Research & Advisory service estimates "that the world still has 500 million to 600 million barrels of free storage space, but not all of it is readily accessible and storage capacity could effectively be filled by June". (Twitter)

PRIMER: CBRT Rate Decision at 12:00BST; Expectations are for a 50bps cut to 9.25% (forecast range 50-100bps cut)
content:
• Although some desks have downplayed the relevance of the Turkish central bank’s policy rate in the current environment, there is a risk it might be subject to another reduction of between 50-100bps from the current 9.75%, and with a downside bias to expectations – consensus for a 50bps cut to 9.25%. That being said, some desks see a sizeable rate hike on the agenda in the near future amid the CBRT’s dwindling reserves situation.
  • In the middle of March, the CBRT conducted an intra-meeting 100bps rate cut and undertook measures to ease liquidity conditions, including 1-year swap auctions – a move amounting to an effective rate cut between 200-250bps, analysts said; additional liquidity measures were also announced at the end of March to cushion the COVID-19 burden. The Bank today also raised the FX-Lira swap market transaction limit to 30% from 20%.
  • The central bank signalled tolerance of a weaker Lira, as USDTRY meanders close to 7.00, with inflationary repercussions countered by the slump in oil prices. Annual inflation ticked lower to 11.86% in March from 12.37% in February, albeit real rates remain negative. The central bank’s April survey saw its year-end CPI view lowered to 9.76% from 9.98%, with the USDTRY forecast upped to 6.9277 from 6.5117, while the Repo Rate view in 12-months was reduced to 8.66% from 9.14%.
  • Analysts at Credit Suisse believe further FX interventions and capital flow restrictions are needed to keep both real rates low and the TRY rate under control to alleviate strains on corporate and bank balance sheets should the pronounced currency weakness materialise.

content:

Another swing in broad risk sentiment amidst less pronounced pressure on oil and other commodities has aided the latest Aussie, Kiwi and Loonie recovery, but with the former also benefiting from a short squeeze in wake of a record rise in retail sales per preliminary data for March. Aud/Usd took some time to digest the release and acknowledge the fact that stock-piling for COVID-19 boosted consumption, but subsequently breached 0.6300 on the way to circa 0.6350 with stops tripped above 0.6325 and macro fund offers over 0.6340 absorbed along the way. Meanwhile, Nzd/Usd retested 0.6000, albeit with a lag as Aud/Nzd rebounded from sub-1.0550 to around 1.0580, and Usd/Cad has retreated between 1.4237-1.4139 parameters on the aforementioned relative stability in crude prices ahead of Canadian CPI.

GBP/SEK/NOK

Sterling has unwound some of its recent underperformance on technical rather than fundamental grounds given Cable remaining above the 30 DMA (1.2257) and revisiting 1.2300+ levels, while Eur/Gbp has reversed towards 0.8800 as the DXY meanders within a tight band on the 100.000 handle and single currency continues to straddle 1.0850. Similarly, the Scandis are seeing some reprieve from oil and pandemic risk aversion, with Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek both off highs near 11.5950 and 10.9700 respectively and the Swedish Krona weighing up more unconventional Riksbank easing in the form of municipal QE in the run up to next week’s official policy meeting.

JPY/EUR/CHF

All sticking to pretty narrow and well trodden recent confines vs the Dollar, as the Yen flits from 107.86 to 107.52, Euro hovers below 1.0900 and above 1.0800 amidst decent option expiry interest at the former (1.5 bn) and 1.0825 (1 bn), and Franc pivots 0.9700.

EM

Softer than expected SA CPI has not hindered the Rand amidst the overall upturn in risk appetite, but the Lira is treading more cautiously into the CBRT even though the Central Bank has already lifted FX swap limit transactions to 30% from 20% in what may be an effort to keep Usd/Try under 7.0000 in the event that rates are cut again, as widely expected, but perhaps more than the -50 bp consensus. On that note, the Mexican Peso seems to have taken Banxico’s emergency ½ point ease in stride or at least lubricated by the less fractious state of trade in crude markets.

Bunds: deeper pull-back from 173.00+ highs ahead of ECB collateral call
content: The 10 year German benchmark has lost more momentum after yesterday’s firm rebound to peaks not seen since the start of the month amidst some, relative stability in oil and a tentative recovery in Italian BTPs. However, the core Eurozone bond is holding above Tuesday’s 172.45 Eurex low between 172.58-95 parameters vs its 172.91 previous close awaiting tomorrow’s EU meeting on a coronavirus fiscal relief package and the outcome of an emergency ECB call said to be planned for later today and to discuss funding collateral. More immediately, eyes on the cash bourse opens with futures indicating a partial bounce and then Italian industrial orders before preliminary Eurozone consumer confidence for April that is expected to fall further below zero, but may surprise to the upside in line with ZEW business sentiment.

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.
